thread.title: Outdoors notebook: Grand Prairie bass bonanza Saturday
thread.title_full: Outdoors notebook: Grand Prairie bass bonanza Saturday | Dallas Morning News

author: Ray Sasser
title: Outdoors notebook: Grand Prairie bass bonanza Saturday
text:
The Optimist Club of Grand Prairie hosts its 11th annual Big Bass Bonanza Fishing Tournament at Joe Pool Lake on Saturday, Oct. 17. This tournament is traditionally held in May but was postponed this year due to high water. Entry details are online at optimistgp.org.
First prize pays $1,500. There are hourly big bass prizes of $100 and gift certificate prizes. Proceeds fund the club's college scholarships. Six scholarships are divided among three Grand Prairie high schools.
The Optimist Club of Grand Prairie has also organized an after-school program to tutor children, a summer reading and lunch program, and is involved in numerous other state and national youth programs.
10-year-old kills 13-foot gator with crossbow Ten-year-old Ella Hawk of Huffman killed a 13-foot alligator with a crossbow Sept. 27 while hunting with her parents, Tony and Cindy Hawk, and professional hunting guide Ryan Longer. The 800-pound reptile was in the lower Guadalupe River south of Victoria.
In accordance with Texas law, the animal was baited and hooked before Ella killed it with her crossbow.
It's not the biggest Texas alligator in recent years. In 2013, Braxton Bielski of Cinco Ranch, hunting with his father, Troy Bielski, killed an alligator measuring 14 feet, 3 inches.
The father-son duo both drew alligator permits for the James Daughtrey Wildlife Management Area at Choke Canyon Reservoir. Just 10 alligator permits were issued that year, and 481 hunters applied through a Texas Parks and Wildlife Department drawing.
Neches River paddling trail launch event set Paddling enthusiasts are invited to help launch the Cherokee Neches Paddling Trail on Saturday, Oct. 17 at 1 p.m. at River Run Park, near Jacksonville in East Texas.
The launch event is hosted by the Jacksonville Chamber of Commerce, Friends of the Neches River, Texas Conservation Alliance and the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. An on-the-river ribbon cutting is planned and lunch will be available.
The Cherokee Neches Paddling Trail is the state's 69th, including five in the Dallas area. Paddling trails are well marked and feature improved and maintained access points.
The Cherokee Neches Paddling Trail is 6.6 miles and takes about three to five hours to complete. Canoe rentals and shuttles can be arranged through riverrunpark.com or call 903-724-4100.
College anglers to compete in Oklahoma FLW College Fishing will host its Southern Conference Championship Oct. 17-18 on Oklahoma's Grand Lake. Twenty-three Texas teams are registered for the competition. A team consists of two anglers.
Included in the field are three teams from Dallas Baptist. Chase Winston of Dallas and Trent Newman of Midlothian fish for Dallas Baptist.
Brian Blades of Terrell, Matthew Anthony of Colleyville and Tyler Woods of Mansfield fish for Texas A&M. Joseph Sanderson of Fort Worth is on the TCU team. A&M has the most teams with nine.
FLW Rookie of the Year Zack Birge of Blanchard, Okla., said he expects the fishing to be good.
